ARTICLE.TITLE: Treasury Wine Estates: Coronavirus stifles exports to US and China
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Penfolds owner Treasury Wine Estates says the coronavirus pandemic has induced major challenges in the wine market, significantly impacting its main export markets the US and China.

Treasury Wine Estates has a posted a net profit of $315.8 million for the 12 months ending June 30, a 25 per cent decrease on its 2019 financial year result.

The company said the second half of the 2020 financial year was riddled with unfavourable volumes and portfolio mixes as a result of COVID-19, which had reduced the demand for luxury wine sales.

It also noted challenging wine market conditions in the US had also impacted sales within its key wine channels, with overall North American earnings before tax and interest declining by 37 per cent to $147.3 million.

media_camera Treasury Wine Estates has a posted a net profit of a $315.8 million for the 12 months ending June 30. Picture: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg

Earnings from Asian exports fell 14 per cent to an EBIT position of $243.7 million, while Australian and New Zealand EBIT declined 16 per cent to $133.3 million.

The company noted Asian consumption and sales were showing positive signs of recovery in the final quarter of financial year 2020.

Treasury Wine Estates said volumes sold in the Chinese market had risen 40 per cent in June compared to the previous corresponding month.

E-commerce sales across its global distributions had accelerated in the second half of the year, as a result of lockdown measures imposed across the world.

Treasury Wine Estates said the ongoing uncertainty induced by the pandemic had made it unable to provide earnings outlooks for the 2021 financial year.

The company has issued a final divided of 8 cents per share, bringing the total dividend payout for the 2020 financial year to 28 cents per share, representing 64 per cent of the total net profit.

“While we have recently seen positive signs of recovery across a number of our key markets and channels, we are cautious on the near-term outlook given the uncertainty that remains around the pace of that recovery,” Treasury Wine Estates chief executive, Tim Ford said.

Originally published as Pandemic stifles wine sales to US and China

METADATA.description: The owner of luxury wine brand Penfolds says the coronavirus pandemic has impacted the companys ability to sell wine in major overseas markets.
METADATA.keywords: seen positive signs, North America, Tim Ford, Gerard Cockburn, net profit, wine market, wine market conditions, Eastern Asia, coronavirus pandemic, America, Northern America, dividend payout, earnings outlooks, portfolio mixes, United States of America, Asian exports, Asia, chief executive, China, luxury wine brand
